instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good‚Äù and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PM_S0_PGOOD: What is PM_S0_PGOOD?  PM_S0_PGOOD is created when CPUVR_PGOOD and ALL_SYS_PWRGD are present and branches off to become PM_PCH_PWROK. PM_S0_PGOOD and SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD are necessary to create SYS_PWROK_R and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK .
definitions.CPUVR_PGOOD: What is CPUVR_PGOOD? CPU_VR_PGOOD Is a signal present when CPU_VR_EN is presenT. CPU_VR_PGOOD is a prerequisite along with ALL_SYS_PWRGD to create PM_S0_PGOOD and PM_PCH_PWROK and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK which are necessary for the machine to turn on and boot..
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> /?<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - power rails but no fan spin
threads.message:
Hi

Bit of a noob here so please excuse the no doubt dumb questions.

I?ve been working on fixing a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Mac Book Air and I?ve got to the point where the main power rails are looking correct but I?m not sure where to go from here.  I'm getting a green then organ light from the charger but no fan spin when powered.

Measured voltages:

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.336
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.401
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3.336
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.589
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5.014
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> = 0.0012
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 0.00

Am I expecting <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> or <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> as soon as the power connector is plugged in? or do I need to hit the keyboard power button.  I notice in Louis? videos he never seems to have a keyboard plugged in or ?do anything? to initiate boot up

Any help much appreciated.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> /?<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - power rails but no fan spin
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

All iCore boards should start automatically when charger is connected, if no battery present.
Try the board itself, disconnecting LIO flex, airport card, internal SSD and trackpad.

Be sure to use original Magsafe 2 charger; post <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> level.

Also post <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_PAWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
If present, check for pulse at all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals at same time.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> /?<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - power rails but no fan spin
threads.message:
Hey there thanks very much! 

Here are some voltages after a bit of probing.  Annoying the damn fan started spinning during the probing, then stopped.

<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = 3.331v
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.341v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> = 3.002v
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> = 3.4003v
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> = 2.734v

My scope is otherwise engaged for the next few hours but it looks like <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is pulsing - difficult to see the frequency on a 8808 but looks like every second or so.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> /?<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - power rails but no fan spin
threads.message:
All <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals should pulse then.
Check for pulse at all big coils, if fan spins.

No need of o-scope.
Repeatedly trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for pulses...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> /?<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - power rails but no fan spin
threads.message:
Yup .. so all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> lines all pulse to 3.2v every 4.2 seconds, the pulse width is about 200ms

By triggering the <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> just pull it to ground?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> /?<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - power rails but no fan spin
threads.message: Well pulling <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R5116</RESISTOR> (OMIT) doesn't seem to have any effect, pulses remain constant.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> /?<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - power rails but no fan spin
threads.message:
You must simulate power button; do NOT maintain <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> to ground, just do temporary contact.

So you are in 5s cycling power loop.
Do you get pulse at L7310/20 too?
What about pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> /?<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - power rails but no fan spin
threads.message:
Yup looks like a power loop to me!

Pulse at L7320 
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_PHASE2</SIGNAL> = 8.5v
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU_PH2</SIGNAL> = 1.75 (ish)

Pulse at L7310
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_PHASE1</SIGNAL> = 8.5v
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL> = 1.75 (ish)

<CHIP>U1950</CHIP>
PIN 3 - <SIGNAL>SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> = pulsing
PIN 7 - <SIGNAL>PM_S0_PGOOD</SIGNAL> = pulsing
PIN 2 - <SIGNAL>CPUVR_PGOOD</SIGNAL> = pulsing
PIN 1 - <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = pulsing

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> /?<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - power rails but no fan spin
threads.message:
Try to start in SMC bypass mode.

Any history fault available?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> /?<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - power rails but no fan spin
threads.message:
History wise, no idea, an acquired laptop :-) Given to me with no more than the words 'it doesn't work'.

The inside didn't look messed with, judging by the thick layer of dust.  The only thing that looked corroded out of place was a bit of corrosion at J6100.

Just working out how to start in SMC bypass mode now

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> /?<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - power rails but no fan spin
threads.message:
Ok - I give up.  Lots of mentioned of people saying they did start up in bypass mode but I cant find out how to do it. 

How exactly does one start up in SMB bypass mode? 

Did I say I was vanilla / a noob / pure with this ?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> /?<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - power rails but no fan spin
threads.message:
Press power button (use the same wire from <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>), connect charger, mantain pressed and release it after 5-10s.

I suppose you don't have Medusa programmer, so I recommend to remove J6100.
Check all SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces; page 46, more than 20 resistors.
If all good, try known good BIOS file (<CHIP>U6100</CHIP>).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> /?<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - power rails but no fan spin
threads.message:
Removing J6100 seems to have sorted it - I should have really just removed/replaced it when I first noticed the corrosion.

Thanks for your help with this.  Much appreciated - can I get you a beer as a thank you somehow?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> /?<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - power rails but no fan spin
threads.message:
Glad to hear is solved.
You should send the beer via UPS/Fedex, if you are not in Madrid ;).
